questions.title: 1When architecting record ownership, what's the suggested parameter for child records per parent to avoid data skew?

answers.content: A No more than 2,000 child records per parent
B No more than 10,000 child records per parent
D There isn't oneâ€”parent-child relationships don't cause data skew.

wrongAnswers.content: C No more than 100,000 child records per parent

correctAnswer.content: B No more than 10,000 child records per parent

questions.title: 2What's the difference between ownership skew and lookup skew?

answers.content: B Ownership skew involves a large number of records with the same object type being owned by a single user, while lookup skew occurs when a large number of records are associated with a single record in the lookup object.

wrongAnswers.content: A Ownership skew can cause record locking, while lookup skew can cause overall performance issues.

C Ownership skew can be caused by adding custom code and a large data volume simultaneously in an automated process, while lookup skew can be caused by parking unassigned records under a generic owner.
D They're essentially the same, but they're associated with different objects within an org.

correctAnswer.content: B Ownership skew involves a large number of records with the same object type being owned by a single user, while lookup skew occurs when a large number of records are associated with a single record in the lookup object.

questions.title: 3Which of these is an ideal scenario for using external objects?

answers.content: D When you have a large amount of data that you don't want to store in your org, and you only need to use a small amount of that data at any one time

wrongAnswers.content: C When you have a large amount of data that you don't want to store in your org, and you need the ability to access all of it at once
A When you have large amounts of data your users don't need to access or search
B When you're below your limit of 100 external objects, and you have a large amount of data to store

correctAnswer.content: D When you have a large amount of data that you don't want to store in your org, and you only need to use a small amount of that data at any one time
